title: N33 Billion Meant for Weapons Bought Land and Funded Saudi Transfers Instead
content:
this is not a movie. this happened in court today.

an efcc investigator stood in front of a judge and started reading numbers. big numbers. the kind that make you stop and wonder if you heard correctly.

n33 billion. thirty-three billion naira. money meant to buy weapons while boko haram was tearing through the northeast. money meant to protect nigeria.

instead, it allegedly funded land purchases, properties in abuja, and dollar transfers to saudi arabia.

what actually happened in court

michael adarikun, an efcc detective, testified about how n2.2 billion - just a piece of the larger n33 billion - moved from the office of the national security adviser under sambo dasuki.

the money was supposed to secure state elections. instead, it went to a private company called acacia holdings limited, owned by aminu baba-kusa, a former nnpc official.

before the money hit? acacia holdings had n27,000 in their account.

after? hundreds of millions started flowing out.

where the money went

the investigator read out the transfers one by one:

  • n600 million here
  • n650 million there
  • n750 million to reliance referral hospital

then it got specific. surgical even.

n70 million to jubril abdullahi. n50 million to baba-kusa himself. n20 million to ec associates. n2 million to a staff member named suraya maigida.

n15 million went to ibrahim saleh - the guy allegedly buying properties for baba-kusa. that payment? it was for 'hospitality property nigeria' through zabati bdc limited.

n250 million withdrawn with the vague label 'miscellaneous customer service.'

another n2 million to saleh to 'facilitate the retention of a plot of land at wuse 2, abuja.' then n25 million more days later.

and the land deals. n60 million allegedly paid to an islamic academy - not for education, but as part payment for 3.62 hectares of land in kyami district opposite centenary city along airport road.

survey fees. beacon processing. stadium layouts. all funded with money meant for weapons.

the saudi arabia transfer

then there's the foreign transfer. n55.9 million moved to facilitate a $1 million transfer.

only $630,000 allegedly made it to saudi arabia.

where did the rest go? nobody said.

context

this is one of several cases stemming from the arms procurement scandal of 2014-2015. president buhari's audit panel found that approximately $2 billion meant for fighting boko haram was unaccounted for.

sambo dasuki was the national security adviser from 2012 to 2015. the height of boko haram's terror campaign. when soldiers were dying because they didn't have proper equipment.

the trial has dragged on for nearly a decade. early on, the sss refused to release dasuki on bail despite multiple court orders. now it's 2026 and we're still hearing testimony about transfers from 2015.

what the defense said

when the efcc tried to enter baba-kusa's statement into evidence, the defense objected. they claimed it was involuntary, made while he was in an efcc underground cell.

the prosecution said the statement was made in a public area with his lawyer present.

the judge ordered a trial-within-a-trial to determine if the statement was voluntary. the case continues on february 24.

the bigger picture

these numbers were read under oath in open court. sworn testimony about money that was supposed to protect nigeria while boko haram was massacring people in the northeast.

n33 billion is a lot of money. enough to equip an army. enough to change the course of a war.

instead, if the allegations are true, it bought land in abuja and facilitated transfers to saudi arabia.

the trial continues.
excerpt: an efcc investigator testified in court about how n33 billion meant for weapons ended up funding land purchases, properties, and foreign transfers
